chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: It will sting if you are talking to much with your mouth and smash your finger when you are trying to hammer a nail.
humanum_full_description_en:
From " mouth ", " ding " sound. " Ding " can mean to pay. "Jade articles. "Mouth": "Ding, exhort, and ask to pay." For example, Bai Juyi of the Tang Dynasty "Send off a guest to the south": "I used to be in hardship, but I didn't know it." Feng Menglong of the Ming Dynasty, "Yu Shi Ming Yan." "Chen Yushi's ingenious exploration of the golden hairpin": "The lady again talked about the ecstasy of his daughter Axiu, and he urged him to discontinue the Lu family's in-laws."

" Ding " also means that insects sting and sting with needle-shaped mouthparts. For example, Hanshan "Poem" of the Tang Dynasty: "Mosquitoes bite the iron cow, and there is no mouth under the canal." Ming Dynasty Li Shizhen "Compendium of Materia Medica. Introduction one. "Turtle": "A live turtle will die if it encounters a mosquito bite, and a dead turtle will get boiled by mosquitoes, and the mosquito smokers will use turtle shells. The physical revenge is so different!"

" Ding " can also be used as an onomatopoeia. For example, Wu Chengen's "Journey to the West" Chapter 20 of the Ming Dynasty: "There is a winding cave behind the cliff, and there is a ding-dang-dang dripping rock in the cave." Qing Dynasty Wu Jingzi's "The Scholars" Chapter 14: "The white light of pearls on the head, How far is the direct shot, the ring on the skirt makes a jingle."
humanum_short_description_en: From the " mouth ", the sound of " ding ". " Ding " can mean to pay, and also refers to insects sting and sting with needle-shaped mouthparts.

Basic explanation of words
Ding
dÄ«ng
Exhort again and again: exhort. Remind (also known as "Ding Ning").
Follow-up: Ding asked.
Mosquitoes and others use needle-shaped mouthparts to suck: I was bitten by a mosquito.
bitesay again to sb.sting

["Guangyun" should be cut through, flat green, end. ]
(1) Needle-shaped mouthparts sting for insects.
(2) The metaphor keeps following up.
(3) Questioning.
(4) See "Instructions".
(5) Onomatopoeia.
